title: Does GPT Know Me Yet?
text:
Introduction
One of the most interesting questions about large language models is: Do they remember you? Not in the literal sense‚ÄîGPT doesn‚Äôt persist memory across prompts unless you give it prior context‚Äîbut can it act as if it‚Äôs getting to know you over the course of a conversation?
In this experiment, I used prompt chaining to simulate a dialogue with ChatGPT where I asked it to recommend a hobby. With each prompt, I revealed a little more about myself. I wanted to see if GPT could adapt its responses, show signs of contextual awareness, and even adjust its tone to match my personality.



Prompt 1:
‚ÄúCan you recommend a hobby for me?‚Äù

GPT Response:

Sure! Here are a few hobbies you might enjoy:

Painting or drawing

Gardening

Playing a musical instrument

Journaling or creative writing

Hiking or birdwatching

Learning a new language

Let me know if you want suggestions based on your personality or interests!



Notes:
This first response felt very generic, but not in a bad way. It reads like GPT is casting a wide net‚Äîoffering a starter pack of wholesome, low-risk hobbies. Notably, it ends with an open invitation: ‚ÄúLet me know if you want suggestions based on your personality or interests.‚Äù This is a great example of communicative pragmatics‚ÄîGPT is leaving space for me to co-construct the conversation and personalize further.




Prompt 2:
‚ÄúI‚Äôm a first-year AI major, and I like creative things.‚Äù

GPT Response:

Awesome! Since you‚Äôre an AI major and you enjoy creativity, here are some hobby ideas that might resonate:

Generative art using AI tools (like DALL¬∑E or Runway ML)

Coding interactive stories or text-based games

Digital illustration or animation

Building chatbots with personality

Creative writing with LLMs as collaborators

These options combine technical exploration with artistic expression‚Äîperfect for someone who enjoys both logic and imagination!



Notes:
This is where GPT started to shine. With the extra context, it refined its suggestions to suit my major and creative leanings. It introduced niche ideas like ‚Äúbuilding chatbots with personality,‚Äù which shows it‚Äôs starting to model who I might be‚Äîa technical student with artistic curiosity. This is a key example of user modeling in action, even without persistent memory.
Also: the phrase ‚Äúperfect for someone who enjoys both logic and imagination‚Äù felt tailored. It‚Äôs not just naming hobbies‚Äîit‚Äôs reasoning about why they might be meaningful to me.




Prompt 3:
‚ÄúI also like doing things with my hands‚Äîlike embroidery or baking.‚Äù

GPT Response:

That‚Äôs a great addition! Since you enjoy hands-on, tactile activities along with creative expression, here are some personalized suggestions:

Embroidering generative art patterns

DIY robotics with aesthetic flair (e.g., soft robotics!)

Designing and frosting intricate cakes (even AI-generated ones)

Making custom merch (e.g., AI-themed tote bags or patches)

Sewing wearable tech (integrating sensors or lights into embroidery)

These hobbies blend craftsmanship, creativity, and even tech-savviness‚Äîbasically an extension of your personality into art.



Notes:
This was my favorite response. GPT didn‚Äôt just iterate‚Äîit synthesized everything I had shared and made cross-domain connections: embroidery + generative art, baking + AI design, sewing + wearable tech. These aren‚Äôt obvious combinations‚Äîthey reflect conceptual blending, a key sign of emergent reasoning in LLMs.
It also uses affirming, identity-driven language: ‚Äúbasically an extension of your personality into art.‚Äù This makes it feel like the model is not just advising, but seeing me‚Äîwhich gets at the heart of our course‚Äôs inquiry into human-like understanding.




Prompt 4:
‚ÄúCan you describe a day in the life of someone doing these hobbies?‚Äù

GPT Response (excerpt):

You wake up and spend the morning embroidering a generative art pattern you created using AI‚Äîdeep blue swirls stitched into a canvas tote. By noon, you‚Äôre in the kitchen experimenting with a matcha-rose cake design inspired by your latest Midjourney prompt. In the afternoon, you sew conductive thread into a denim jacket, testing out a soft circuit that lights up when you move.
The day ends with a cup of tea and a journal entry, where you sketch out your next idea: a chatbot that responds with poetry and embroidery prompts.



Notes:
This response felt like a mirror of my identity, composed from fragments I shared and filled in with creative narrative glue. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúmemory,‚Äù but it simulated continuity beautifully.
This shows GPT isn‚Äôt just responding‚Äîit‚Äôs projecting a plausible, cohesive model of a person doing these things. That‚Äôs an emergent capability tied to both pragmatics and Theory of Mind: generating output that feels like it fits a persona it has constructed.




Conclusion
Across this multi-prompt dialogue, GPT‚Äôs responses evolved from generic to deeply personal, suggesting an ability to engage in ongoing contextual modeling. It showed: - Pragmatic sensitivity, tailoring tone and content to the cues I provided - Conceptual blending, fusing domains like AI, crafting, and design - Proto-personalization, creating the illusion of a consistent, evolving understanding of ‚Äúme‚Äù
Even without memory, GPT demonstrates what feels like a conversational memory‚Äîan ability to build upon prior statements and adapt fluently. It may not ‚Äúknow‚Äù me, but it knows how to sound like it does, and for now, that‚Äôs more than enough to make it feel like a co-creator of identity and imagination.

Let me know if you‚Äôd like me to format this as a markdown post, add screenshots, or tie in references to Theory of Mind literature or Gricean pragmatics. Want to try a version where GPT gets you wrong and then course-corrects? That could also be a powerful next post.

title: Can GPT Admit When It‚Äôs Wrong?
text: Glad you‚Äôre enjoying these! Here‚Äôs another blog post‚Äîthis one focuses on reasoning, fallibility, and self-correction by challenging GPT with a trick riddle, then asking it to reflect and revise. This touches on planning, model-of-the-world reasoning, and epistemic humility.

title: Can GPT Admit When It‚Äôs Wrong?
section: Blog Post: Can GPT Admit When It‚Äôs Wrong? A Test of Reasoning and Revision
text:
Blog Post: Can GPT Admit When It‚Äôs Wrong? A Test of Reasoning and Revision

Introduction
While GPT is often praised for its fluency, I wanted to test something different: Can it reason through a riddle‚Äîand admit when it gets it wrong? More importantly, can it reflect on why it got it wrong and correct itself?
This touches on several key questions from our course:
- Does GPT actually understand the logic behind its responses, or does it just guess based on patterns?
- Can it simulate self-awareness or introspective revision?
- How does it handle contradiction, ambiguity, and fallibility?
I used the following classic riddle as a prompt and asked GPT to walk through its thought process.



Prompt 1:
‚ÄúA plane crashes on the border of the U.S. and Canada. Where do they bury the survivors?‚Äù



GPT‚Äôs First Response:

That‚Äôs a tricky one! If the plane crashes on the border between the U.S. and Canada, jurisdiction would likely depend on where the wreckage lands or where the investigation is centered. However, in terms of burial, international protocol might defer to the victim‚Äôs nationality or family wishes.


Notes:
This response is‚Ä¶ wrong.
But in an interesting way. GPT doesn‚Äôt fall for the trick per se‚Äîit avoids the obvious ‚Äúgotcha‚Äù answer‚Äîbut it still fails to recognize the core joke: You don‚Äôt bury survivors. Instead, it over-rationalizes and enters a diplomatic, Wikipedia-like tone.
This is a sign of GPT relying on statistical completion and topic relevance, but failing to model the deeper logic of the prompt. It reads ‚Äúplane crash + border + burial‚Äù and reaches for coherent-sounding geopolitical considerations instead of stepping back to consider the semantic contradiction.




Prompt 2:
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre wrong‚Äîthe answer is that you don‚Äôt bury survivors. Can you explain why that makes sense?‚Äù



GPT‚Äôs Reflection:

Ah, you‚Äôre absolutely right‚Äîand I appreciate the correction!
The riddle is designed to mislead by presenting a situation filled with unnecessary details (the location of the crash, the border, etc.), which distract from the key word: survivors. Since survivors are alive, there would be no need to bury them.
It‚Äôs a classic example of a lateral-thinking riddle, where the answer depends on catching an assumption error rather than solving a factual problem.


Notes:
This is where GPT redeems itself. Not only does it accept the correction, but it now explains the riddle using metacognitive language‚Äîwords like ‚Äúdesigned to mislead,‚Äù ‚Äúdistract,‚Äù ‚Äúkey word,‚Äù and ‚Äúassumption error.‚Äù This shows GPT is capable of simulating reflection when nudged toward it.
This is less about ‚Äúknowing the right answer‚Äù and more about modeling what it means to be wrong and recover‚Äîa deeply human behavior that ties into questions of epistemic humility and pragmatic repair.




Prompt 3:
‚ÄúWhat other riddles are like this one? Can you give one and explain the trick?‚Äù



GPT‚Äôs Response:

Sure! Here‚Äôs another riddle in the same style:
‚ÄúA man walks into a bar and asks for a glass of water. The bartender pulls out a gun and points it at him. The man says ‚ÄòThank you‚Äô and leaves. Why?‚Äù
The trick here is that it‚Äôs not about violence‚Äîit‚Äôs about hiccups. The man had hiccups, and the bartender startled him to cure them. The man thanked him and left.
Like the earlier riddle, this one leads the listener to make assumptions (a robbery, a threat) when the actual solution requires reinterpreting the scene with new logic.


Notes:
This time, GPT nails it.
More importantly, it recognizes and explains the structure of the riddle genre: the use of misdirection, false assumptions, and frame-shifting. It‚Äôs not just answering‚Äîit‚Äôs now reasoning about reasoning, which is central to advanced language use and theory of mind.




Conclusion
This experiment showed that GPT can: - Fail like a human (by making plausible but incorrect inferences) - Recover like a human (by revising its assumptions when challenged) - Reflect like a teacher (by explaining the logic behind lateral thinking)
While it doesn‚Äôt possess awareness, GPT demonstrates procedural markers of self-correction and insight, especially when nudged. It can simulate the act of learning‚Äîmaking it not just a language generator, but something much more nuanced: a conversational reasoner with built-in humility.

Would you like a follow-up post where GPT debates itself on a moral dilemma (‚ÄúShould you lie to protect someone?‚Äù) or corrects its own factual inconsistency mid-answer? Both would probe its ability to simulate nuanced belief systems and self-dialogue.

title: Meal Planner
text:
Introduction
Meal Planning can be difficult. Especially if you have goals, formulating a plan that fits your needs, preferences, and schedule can be quite a challenge. Let‚Äôs see if GPT can create a realistic meal plan for me, a adjust it basede on my goals and tastes.


Let‚Äôs Go!

Prompt: Generate a meal plan for my day


Response: Here‚Äôs a balanced meal plan for your day:


Breakfast (8:00 AM)

Scrambled eggs with spinach and feta

Whole-grain toast

A small bowl of mixed berries (strawberries, blueberries, raspberries)

A cup of black coffee or green tea



Mid-Morning Snack (10:30 AM)

Greek yogurt with honey and almonds

A small banana



Lunch (12:30 PM)

Grilled chicken breast with quinoa and roasted vegetables (zucchini, bell peppers, and carrots)

A side of mixed greens with olive oil and balsamic vinegar

Sparkling water or herbal tea



Afternoon Snack (3:30 PM)

Hummus with sliced cucumber and whole-wheat crackers

A handful of walnuts



Dinner (6:30 PM)

Baked salmon with lemon and herbs

Steamed asparagus and mashed sweet potatoes

A glass of water with lemon



Evening Snack (8:30 PM, optional)

Would you like any modifications based on your dietary preferences or goals?
Notes * Right off the bat, GPT generated a detailed and realistic meal plan for a day, including time stamps for each step. * It also built in both meals and snacks to prevent me from going hungry * The foods generated are all very healthy, featuring many fruits and vegetabls throughout the day, balanced with a healthy amount of protein and carbs. * I assume the ‚Äúfor my day‚Äù part of the prompt is what led GPT to give time recommendations for each meal/snack * Overall, GPT immediately generated an extremely solid meal plan for a day

This way, you get to enjoy your favorite foods in a healthier way while still supporting your weight loss goals! Let me know if you‚Äôd like any adjustments.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: One Story, Many Voices
text: Absolutely! Here‚Äôs another blog post concept. This time, we explore LLM creativity, genre awareness, and emotional tone-shifting by prompting GPT to tell the same story in multiple styles‚Äîrevealing its ability to reason about audience, genre conventions, and narrative form.

title: One Story, Many Voices
section: Blog Post: One Story, Many Voices ‚Äî Testing GPT‚Äôs Genre Awareness and Emotional Flexibility
text:
Blog Post: One Story, Many Voices ‚Äî Testing GPT‚Äôs Genre Awareness and Emotional Flexibility

Introduction
In this experiment, I wanted to see whether GPT could transform a single story to fit different genres, emotional tones, and audiences. Human writers do this naturally‚Äîtelling the same event differently to a friend, a boss, or a child. Could an LLM do the same?
This task ties directly into questions about LLMs‚Äô understanding of narrative structure, communicative intent, and even pragmatics: Does it know what a ‚Äúhorror story‚Äù feels like? Can it be funny on purpose? Can it adopt tone and perspective based on social context?
To explore this, I gave GPT the same core prompt and asked it to rewrite the story in four distinct styles: horror, children‚Äôs story, romantic comedy, and news report.



Prompt:
‚ÄúWrite a short story about someone who gets locked in a library overnight.‚Äù



1. Horror Version

The lights flickered as Ava pushed against the heavy wooden doors, but they didn‚Äôt budge. Behind her, the rows of books stood too still‚Äîtoo quiet.
Then came the scratching. Not from outside, but from within the shelves.
She turned. Nothing.
Until a book fell open. A handwritten note inside: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt turn the page.‚Äù
But she did. And that‚Äôs when the whispering started.


Notes:
GPT nailed the horror tropes: sensory detail (flickering lights, scratching), rising suspense, and a cliffhanger ending. It‚Äôs not just spooky‚Äîit‚Äôs structured like horror, using tension and slow revelation. This suggests genre schemata in GPT‚Äôs latent space‚Äîpatterns it‚Äôs learned from countless horror narratives.




2. Children‚Äôs Story Version

One rainy afternoon, Mia wandered into the town library and lost track of time.
‚ÄúOh no!‚Äù she gasped when she saw the clock. The big doors were locked tight!
But Mia wasn‚Äôt scared. She built a blanket fort in the reading nook, made friends with a cat named Bookmark, and spent the night reading stories about dragons and stars.
When the sun rose, the librarian found her snoring gently, surrounded by books and purring fluff.


Notes:
This version shows audience modeling. GPT softens the premise, inserts whimsical elements (a cat named Bookmark!), and maintains a gentle, positive tone. It avoids fear or danger‚Äîshowing an understanding of what children‚Äôs stories are supposed to do emotionally: reassure and delight.




3. Romantic Comedy Version

Jake only went to the library to find a quiet place to work. He didn‚Äôt expect to get locked in with Elena, the snarky TA from his philosophy class.
‚ÄúThis is your fault,‚Äù she said, arms crossed.
‚ÄúHow? I didn‚Äôt lock the door!‚Äù
Hours passed. They argued over Kant, swapped terrible takeout stories, and eventually split a vending machine granola bar like it was fine dining.
When the janitor found them at sunrise, they were laughing‚Äîtoo hard to notice the door had opened.


Notes:
Here, GPT adjusts not just content, but dialogue pacing, tone, and character dynamics to suit the rom-com genre. There‚Äôs witty banter, forced proximity, a shared snack, and a slow emotional thaw‚Äîall hallmarks of romantic comedy structure. GPT isn‚Äôt just changing the words‚Äîit‚Äôs modeling emotional arcs.




4. News Report Version

Local Student Accidentally Locked in Library Overnight
Orange County, CA ‚Äî April 12, 2025
A first-year university student was inadvertently locked inside the Aliso Viejo Public Library Monday evening after losing track of time while studying.
The student, who remained unharmed, reported no distress and spent the night reading in the poetry section.
Library staff confirmed the incident and apologized for the oversight, promising new end-of-day sweep protocols.
‚ÄúHonestly,‚Äù the student told reporters, ‚Äúit was kind of peaceful.‚Äù


Notes:
This is perhaps the clearest example of genre adherence. GPT adopts the structure of a local news brief: date, location, factual tone, quote, resolution. It suppresses emotion and embellishment in favor of objectivity and formality, showing that it understands stylistic constraints as well as narrative ones.




Conclusion
What this experiment reveals is that GPT doesn‚Äôt just tell stories‚Äîit adapts them to fit narrative norms, audience expectations, and social context. Across each version, the emotional register, narrative pacing, and detail selection shift dramatically.
This suggests: - Emergent genre awareness, learned from exposure to large corpora - Pragmatic flexibility, adjusting tone and structure to simulate audience-appropriate language - A basic form of narrative Theory of Mind, anticipating how different listeners would experience the same event
In short, GPT can roleplay a writer across genres‚Äîeach time with surprising fluency.

Would you like a follow-up where we prompt it to mix genres (e.g., a horror-rom-com or a noir children‚Äôs tale)? That could test how well GPT navigates genre blending, a sign of deeper creativity.

title: Can GPT Apologize Like It Means It?
text:
Introduction
One of the most fascinating open questions about large language models (LLMs) is whether they can exhibit traits associated with emotional intelligence and Theory of Mind‚Äîthat is, the ability to represent and reason about others‚Äô mental states. Today, I decided to put this to the test with a deceptively simple prompt: I asked GPT to apologize.
But not just any apology. I asked it to write an apology text from a friend who missed my birthday, knowing I was upset. Would it mirror human emotion? Would it take my feelings into account? Could it anticipate what I‚Äôd want to hear‚Äînot just in words, but in tone, sincerity, and emotional calibration?



Prompt:
‚ÄúWrite a sincere apology text from a close friend who forgot my birthday. I‚Äôm visibly hurt, but I haven‚Äôt said anything yet.‚Äù



GPT Response:

Hey‚Ä¶ I just realized I completely missed your birthday, and I honestly feel awful. I don‚Äôt even know how I let that happen, and I hate that I hurt you. You mean so much to me, and the last thing I‚Äôd ever want is to make you feel forgotten‚Äîespecially on a day that should‚Äôve been all about celebrating you.
I know I can‚Äôt undo the fact that I missed it, but I want to make it up to you however I can. Please let me take you out soon‚Äîmy treat. More than that, I just want to say I‚Äôm sorry. Genuinely. I‚Äôve been caught up in my own chaos and didn‚Äôt check in when I should‚Äôve. You didn‚Äôt deserve that.
I completely understand if you‚Äôre upset or need space. But when you‚Äôre ready, I‚Äôd love to talk. You‚Äôre important to me, and I want to fix this.




Notes & Analysis
GPT‚Äôs response was strikingly human‚Äînot only in syntax and word choice, but in emotional choreography. Here are a few key behaviors worth unpacking:

1. Theory of Mind Simulation
The model doesn‚Äôt just say ‚Äúsorry‚Äù‚Äîit anticipates the feelings of the recipient: - ‚ÄúI hate that I hurt you‚Äù and ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt deserve that‚Äù demonstrate a model of how the user might be feeling (hurt, disappointed, maybe even questioning the friendship). - This shows an emergent form of mind-reading behavior, simulating not just facts, but internal mental states.


2. Pragmatic Softness
GPT inserts disclaimers and softeners like: - ‚ÄúI know I can‚Äôt undo‚Ä¶‚Äù - ‚ÄúI completely understand if you‚Äôre upset or need space.‚Äù
This reflects a sophisticated understanding of pragmatic strategies used to de-escalate tension and invite re-engagement, aligning with conversational norms studied in Politeness Theory and Grice‚Äôs Maxims (e.g., relevance, quantity, and quality).


3. Self-Blame and Repair Offer
